BUSINESS ORGANIZATION

Business Organization is an undertaking which involves investment of fund and risks with the aim of providing goods and services. 

Business organization includes both the firm and the industry. Which may be owned by private individuals (private enterprise) or owned by the government (public enterprise). 

Sometimes both the government and individuals can jointly own and run a business, enterprise. This. is called joint enterprise.

 

Firm

A firm is the basic unit within which factors of production are organized for the purpose of producing wealth or goods and services. A firm is a business unit. It is an arm of an industry that is engaged in the production of a particular brand of a commodity. 

Examples of firms are Innoson Plc., First Bank Plc.etc. 

 

Industry

An industry is a group of firms producing similar products. Examples are bread industry (which comprises of Agege, Nwabueze bread, lion bread etc).

 

Classification of Business Organization

They are broadly classified into two

(i)                 Private enterprises 

(ii)               Public enterprises

 

Types of Business Enterprises 

(a)   The major types of business enterprises are: 

(b)   Sole-proprietorship 

(c)   The partnership 

(d)   The limited liability companies/joint stock companies (Private and Public).

(e)   Co-operative Societies

(f)    Public enterprises 

(g)   Joint enterprise. 

 

 

 

Private Enterprise

Private enterprises are forms of business organization owned and run by private individuals (one or more persons) with the aim of making profits. Examples are sole Proprietorship, partnership, limited liability companies and co-operative societies. 

 

Public Enterprise

Public enterprises are business enterprises owned and run by the government or its agencies. They are not profit-making organizations. The main aim of establishment is to 'provide essential goods and services at affordable prices. This is to ensure that the welfare of the people increases. Examples: Public corporations, Marketing Boards, Welfare Service Boards or Commission etc. 

 

Features of Private Enterprises

(a)   Private ownership

(b)   The aim of private enterprises is to maximize profits.

(c)   The management and organization are undertaken by private individuals. 

(d)   The owners bear the risk

 

The Sole-Proprietorship (One Man Business) 

The sole proprietorship is a type of business organization that is owned and controlled by a single person. He may be helped by his relatives in the running of the business.

 

Features of Sole-Proprietorship

(a)   One-man business

(b)   Capital are sourced from saving and borrowing from friends and bank.

(c)   He bears the risk alone

(d)   Not a limited liability and thus, private property could be sold upon business failure. 

(e)   Not a legal entity

(f)    No board of directors

 

Merits

  1. Easy decision making
  2. Easy management
  3. Close relationship between owner and customers
  4. Small capital requirement, easy to set up.

 

Demerits

  1. Uncertainty of continuity
  2. Unlimited liability
  3. Limited capital
  4. Not a legal entity
  5. No specialization and division of labour

 

The Partnership 

The partnership is a form of business organization in which two or more persons combine their resources together to run a business in order to make profits. They share in the risks and profits of the business. In ordinary business, membership ranges from 2 to 20 while in banking; it is from 2 to 10. Partnership is set by a written agreement which is called “the Deed of Partnership.

 

Features of Partnership

  1. Membership ranges from 2 to 20 while in banking business
  2. Each member contributes capital and skill
  3. Decision is made by partners
  4. No board of directors
  5. Not a legal entity

 

Merits

  1. Easy to raise capital
  2. Partners share risk
  3. Greater continuity

 

Demerits

  1. Delay in decision making
  2. Division of members can end the business
  3. Unlimited liability
  4. Limited capital
  5. Not a legal entity
  6. No specialization and division of labour

 

Limited Liability Companies or Joint-Stock Companies 

Limited Liability Company is a form of business organization farmed by two or more persons who contribute their resources together through the purchase of shares with. the aim of making profits. The owners of the business are called the shareholders. 

Board of directors is elected to manage the business. 

A limited liability company is formed by registering with the registrar of companies with two legal documents 

(i)                 Memorandum of Association which regulates the behaviour of the business with the outside world its particulars. 

(ii)               Articles of association which sets out the internal arrangements for the management of the business. 

 

The joint-stock company is divided into two

Private limited liability companies

Public limited liability companies 

 

Features of Private Limited Liability Companies  

(a)   The number of shareholders ranges from two to fifty persons (2 – 50).

(b)   Capital comes from the shares of members

(c)   It is a legal entity

(d)   Controlled by board of directors

(e)   Shares are not easily transferrable

(f)    There is continuity

(g)   Privacy of account

 

Merits

(a)   Easy to raise capital

(b)   A legal entity

(c)   Share holders have limited liability

(d)   Not bound by law

(e)   Greater chance of continuity

(f)    limited liability

 

Demerits

(a)   Shares can’t be sold and not easily transferrable

(b)   Far relationship between owner and customers

(c)   Delayed decision making

(d)   Pays cooperate tax

(e)   Not easy to set up

 

Features of Public Limited Liability Companies  

(a)   The number of shareholders ranges from seven to infinity.

(b)   The shareholders have limited liability

(c)   Capital comes from the shares of members

(d)   It is a legal entity

(e)   Controlled by board of directors

(f)    Shares are easily transferrable

(g)   There is continuity

(h)   Privacy of account

 

Merits

(a)   Easy to raise capital

(b)   A legal entity

(c)   Share holders have limited liability

(d)   Not bound by law

(e)   Greater Chance of continuity

(f)    limited liability

 

Demerits

(a)   Shares can’t be sold and not easily transferrable

(b)   Far relationship between owner and customers

(c)   Delayed decision making

(d)   Pays cooperate tax

(e)   Not easy to set up

(f)    There is no privacy

 

Difference between Private and Public limited liability company

Membership ranges from 2 to 50 in private limited company but it is from 7 and above in public limited company. 

Shareholders in public limited company can easily transfer their shares without the consents of other shareholders but in a private limited company, it is not so. Employees of a public limited company can easily buy shares in the company but they cannot buy shares in a private limited company. 

In public limited company, shares can be quoted in the stock exchange market while it is not so in a private limited company. 

The accounts of a public limited company are made public while the accounts of a private limited company are not publicized to the public. 

 

Co-Operative Societies 

A co-operative society is a type of business organization formed by producers or consumers with common interest in order to protect their interests. 

 

Features of Co-Operative Societies 

  1. Profit of the business is shared on the basis of patronage.
  2. The shares of members are not transferable.
  3. Co-operative society is a Democratic form of business organization. Its voting system is one man one vote.
  4. They are not taxed.
  5. There is no limit to the number of members.
  6. The members have unlimited liability.
  7. Initial capital is raised through the sale of shares to the members in the form of pooling their resources together.
  8. The business is not a legal entity.

 

Types of Co-operative Societies 

In West Africa, there are three types of Co-operative societies. 

1. The Consumers’ co-operatives 

2. The Producers’ co-operatives 

3. The Credit and thrift co-operatives. 

 

Merits

  1. Goods are sold cheaply to members
  2. Credit and thrift cooperative help members develop habit of savings
  3. Increases standard of living of members
  4. Source of loans to members

 

Demerits

  1. Inexperienced management
  2. Delayed decision making
  3. Unlimited liability
  4. Corruption and Fraud

 

Public Enterprise 

Public enterprises are large scale business units owned and managed by government or state, with the main aim of providing goods and services to the public at cheaper rates. They are set up by law. They can also be called Public Corporations, Authority and Boards. 

NB: Public corporation is different from public limited liability company discussed earlier.

Examples of public enterprises are; Power Holding Company of Nigeria (PHCN), Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), Enugu State Broadcasting Corporation, etc. 

Statutory corporations are public enterprises brought into existence by a special act of parliament which defines its power and functions, rules and regulation governing its employees and its relationship with different departments in the organization. 

 

Features of Public Enterprises 

1. The main objective of public enterprises is to increase the welfare of the citizens at cheap rate and not profit maximization.

2. They are set up by law or act of parliament and they are owned by government. 

3. Government provides the capital.

4. Appointed Board of directors

5. They are legal entities

6. Government bears the risk.

 

Merits

  1. Enjoys monopoly
  2. Creates employment
  3. Source of government revenue
  4. Continuity is enabled
  5. They are source of government revenue

 

Demerits

  1. There is no personal relationship with customers
  2. Political instability due to changes in leaders.
  3. Poor management
  4. Corrupt practices

 

Quoted and unquoted Companies 

Quoted companies are business enterprises whose shares are bought and sold at the stock exchange market. Examples include all public limited liability companies. 

Unquoted companies are business enterprises whose shares are not traded on the stock exchange. market. Examples include all private limited liability companies. 

 

PUME Examples

Example

Privatization of government-owned companies means the

A. relinquishing of government's equity participation to private individuals,

B. recapitalization of government-owned companies

C. joint participation of government and private individuals 

D. commercialization and deregulation of the economy

A (2005/2006, no 13)

relinquishing of government's equity participation to private individuals

 

Example

Joint-stock companies can raise funds from___.

A. the money market B. the capital market

C. various sources. D. government

B (2008/2009, no 12).

The capital markets

 

Example

A major difference between a state- owned enterprise and a private enterprise is that the former____.

A. is not expected to cover its cost of production while the latter is

B. is not always expected to maximize profits while the latter is

C. has shareholders while the latter does not

D. has a board of directors while the latter does not

B (2010/2011, no 7).

is not always expected to maximize profits while the latter is

State- owned enterprises are majorly focused at provision of social services while private owned enterprises are focused at making profits from their investment.

 

Example

The main handicap of sole proprietorship is ____.

A. limited liability. B. lack of technical know-how

C. low profit margin. D. inadequate capital

D. inadequate capital

 

Example

The basic principles of co-operative societies are those of____.

A. active participation of capitalists in the affairs of co-operative societies

B. worker ownership and owner control

C. sole proprietorship. D. partnership. E. denying of credit facilities to members

B (2011/2012, no 4).

worker ownership and owner control

 

Example

The basic principles of co-operative societies are those of____.

A. active participation of capitalists in the affairs of co-operative societies

B. workers ownership and worker control

C. sole proprietorship

D. partnership

B. workers ownership and worker control

 

Example

The type of business organization mostly used for producing public goods in Nigeria is____.

A. sole proprietorships

B. limited liability companies

C. co-operative societies

D. statutory corporations

D. statutory corporations

Statutory corporations are public enterprises brought into existence by a special act of parliament which defines its power and functions, rules and regulation governing its employees and its relationship with different departments in the organization.

 

Example

A public liability company is run on a daily basis by_____.

A. the chief executive. B. the shareholders

C. the board of directors. D. financial consultants

A (2017/2018, no 7)

the chief executive

A public limited company also known as joint stock company; it is a kind of business unit that operates as a separate legal entity from its owners. Public limited company is headed by a board of directors, and the chief executive run the daily activities of the company. It is formed and owned by shareholders. 

 

 

Example

An important feature of a cartel is that___.

A. members do not reduce price below the cartel price

B. each member has a fixed output above which it is not expected to produce

C. a powerful member fixes the price at which others will sell

D. members fix the prices for their products

B (2018/2019, no 14).

each member has a fixed output above which it is not expected to produce

A cartel is a group of businesses or a combination of independent commercial and industrial enterprises that agree to fix prices so they all will make more money; they can limit or control the supply of a commodity to avoid competition and to make more money. 

 

JAMB Examples

Example

The minimum number of shareholders for partnership is 

A. 7 

B. 4 

C. 2 

D. 3

C. 2

 

Example

A major disadvantage of partnership business is

A. difficulty in the transfer of shares

B. distrust among members

C. limited liability

D. large capital outlay

B. distrust among members

 

Example

The transfer to public shareholding corporations to private enterprises is

A. concession

B. incorporation

C. commercialization

D. privatization

D. privatization

 

Example

The maximum number of shareholders for a limited liability company is

A. twenty

B. five

C. seven

D. infinite

D.  infinite

The number of shareholders for private limited liability company ranges from two to fifty persons (2 – 50).

The number of shareholders for public limited liability company ranges from seven to infinity.

 

Example

In a limited liability company, the greatest risk is borne by the 

A. preference shareholders 

B. debentures shareholders 

C. ordinary shareholders 

D. board of directors.

C. ordinary shareholders 

 

Example

A distinguishing characteristic of consumer co-operative society is that the

A. the maximum number of shareholders is 20

B. members are the owners

C. members are the workers

D. the minimum number of shareholders is 5

B. members are the owners

 

Example

The voting power in co-operative societies is vested on

A. management

B. members without loan

C. shareholders

D. members with the highest contribution

C. shareholders

 

Example

The major advantage of a public limited liability company over a private limited liability company's 

A. limited liability enjoyed by owner 

B. separate legal entity 

C. easy transferability of shares 

D. perpetual existence

C. easy transferability of shares
